content.value_statement: Creating research posters for conferences requires careful formatting and visual design. This skill provides HTML/CSS poster templates that export directly to PDF or PPTX formats for professional scientific presentations.
actual_capabilities: Creates HTML/CSS research poster templates at standard sizes (36x48 inches, A0)
Exports posters to PDF via browser print function
Converts HTML posters to PPTX format when needed
Integrates AI-generated visuals and graphics into poster layout
Provides quality checklists for poster review and validation
Includes design principles for scientific poster layouts
limitations: Only creates HTML/CSS posters, not LaTeX (use latex-posters skill for LaTeX output)
PPTX export may require additional conversion tools like LibreOffice
User must generate visual elements separately using image generation skills

prompt_templates.title: Basic poster request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a research poster about [TOPIC] using HTML/CSS template. The poster should include sections for Introduction, Methods, Results, and Conclusions. Export it to PDF format.

prompt_templates.title: Conference poster
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 36x48 inch conference poster for [CONFERENCE NAME] about [RESEARCH TOPIC]. Include AI-generated figures for the methods and results sections. Export to PDF.

prompt_templates.title: PPTX requirement
prompt_templates.prompt: I need a research poster in PPTX format for [TOPIC]. Use the pptx-posters skill to create an HTML poster first, then convert it to PowerPoint format.

prompt_templates.title: Visual-heavy poster
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a poster about [TOPIC] where 60-70% is AI-generated visuals. Generate a hero image, workflow diagram, and results chart first, then integrate them into the HTML poster template.

output_examples.input: Create a research poster about machine learning optimization techniques for a conference
output: Generated HTML poster template at 36x48 inches with professional styling
Created sections: Introduction, Methods, Results, Conclusions
Included placeholders for AI-generated figures (hero, workflow, results chart)
Ready for PDF export via browser print or PPTX conversion

best_practices: Generate visual elements (hero image, diagrams, charts) before creating the HTML poster
Follow the 800-word maximum limit and 60-70% visual content ratio for effective posters
Use browser print function with background graphics enabled for PDF export
anti_patterns: Using this skill for standard posters without PPTX requirement (use latex-posters instead)
Overcrowding posters with too much text or more than 6 sections
Forgetting to enable 'background graphics' when printing to PDF

faq.question: When should I use this skill versus latex-posters?
faq.answer: Use pptx-posters only when user explicitly requests PPTX, PowerPoint, or HTML format. Default to latex-posters for standard academic conference posters.

faq.question: How do I export the poster to PDF?
faq.answer: Open the HTML poster in Chrome or Firefox, press Cmd/Ctrl+P, select Save as PDF, set paper size to match poster dimensions, enable Background graphics.

faq.question: Can I edit the poster in PowerPoint after creation?
faq.answer: Yes, convert the PDF to PPTX using LibreOffice or an online converter, then edit in PowerPoint. Some formatting may need adjustment.

faq.question: What poster sizes are supported?
faq.answer: Standard sizes include 36x48 inches (most common), A0, A1. The HTML template uses 2592x3456 points (36x48 inches).

faq.question: How do I add my own images and figures?
faq.answer: Generate images first using scientific-schematics or Nano Banana Pro skills, save to figures/ directory, then update image src attributes in HTML.

faq.question: What is the recommended text-to-visual ratio?
faq.answer: For effective research posters, aim for 60-70% AI-generated visuals and 30-40% text content, with maximum 800 words total.
